Exophiala viscosa is a species of fungus that belongs to the genus Exophiala, which is a group of ascomycetous fungi commonly known as "black yeasts." This species is characterized by its slimy, viscous colonies that appear dark in color, typically ranging from black to dark brown.

Exophiala viscosa is known to be a thermotolerant and osmotolerant fungus, meaning it can grow and thrive in a wide range of temperatures and high-osmotic environments. It is often found in soil, water, and various other environmental niches.

Microscopically, Exophiala viscosa exhibits septate hyphae, which are branched filamentous structures typical of fungi. It also produces yeast-like cells, as well as conidiophores (specialized structures that bear spores) that can give rise to dark-pigmented, slimy conidia (asexual spores).

This species has been studied for its potential applications in biotechnology, such as its ability to degrade and bioremediate certain pollutants. Additionally, Exophiala viscosa has been investigated for its potential as a causative agent of opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals, although its clinical significance is still being explored.
